author: mosheblox
content: Hi, apologies if it's already been answered, assuming mev-boost will be ready for mainnet, what's to prevent some builders from just faking high bids and just not paying proposers what they claim, as there's no payment proof mechanism yet?

author: sky.cactus
content: I *believe* the relay is implicitly trusted at this phase, and they are the ones that validate that.

author: sky.cactus
content: Under MEV Boost, relayers are trusted and builders are untrusted.

author: jgm
content: And how many relayers do we expect to see that are not themselves block builders?  From what I can tell, the answer is "0" so the question seems relevant (even ignoring the question of collusion between builder and relayer).

author: sky.cactus
content: I think the *expectation* at launch is that there will be 1-2 relayers, and they are *not* block builders.

author: sky.cactus
content: Of course, we have no in-protocol mechanisms to actually enforce/validate this claim.

author: sky.cactus
content: The above expectation is purely a social one.

author: sky.cactus
content: The current situation is basically, "we have a problem today and we would rather Flashbots build a solution than some anonymous darknet actor build a solution because we kinda trust flashbots a little bit, but we really need to find an actually good fix for this long term (PBS)".

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't think anyone believes the current situation of MEV Boost to be ideal in any way.  It is a hacky patch until we can implement PBS.

author: jgm
content:
Do you know who those relayers are?

Can't say that I'm at all comfortable with the vast majority of validators on the network feeding through one or two chokepoints, especially as the relays themselves do not appear to be open source.  Given the huge efforts that have been worked through to decentralize Ethereum's proof of stake operation, it does seem to be massively self-defeating to do this.  But I'm also aware that this ship appears to have sailed.

author: sky.cactus
content: Flashbots team runs one, I don't know if there are others expected at launch.

author: sky.cactus
content: The problem existed prior to The Merge, and it will continue to exist after The Merge.  I don't think this failure is related to The Merge or Proof of Stake at all.  It is just that we (Ethereum community) have not prioritized fixing this problem (which requires PBS).

author: sky.cactus
content: I agree with your sentiment though, this is a real problem that **SHOULD** be addressed ASAP.

author: sky.cactus
content: I would like to see PBS prioritized more than it is currently prioritized as the system is currently operating with an incentive misalignment.

author: mosheblox
content:
Is there a bigger concern than bid faking? Won't payment proofs be sufficient in the meantime? (as proposed in #99 -- https://github.com/flashbots/mev-boost/issues/99)
Though, it isn't realistic to expect #99 before The Merge, right?

author: sky.cactus
content: My biggest concern with the current design is the fact that the relay can take Ethereum offline for a notable period of time if most validators are using it (block witholding).

author: sky.cactus
content: I believe code is being added to the sidecar to constrain how long things can be offline before the system recovers, but I am very uncomfortable with an actor having the ability to turn off block production for minutes at a time (it opens up many attack vectors against contracts that depend on liveness).

author: mosheblox
content: Block withholding? Can't clients just fall back to produce with local EE after they didn't receive the payload?

author: mosheblox
content: Wait, they won't because they risk slashing? ðŸ˜„

author: sky.cactus
content: The problem is that clients commit to a block before they see its body, and the relay can then withold the body.

author: sky.cactus
content: In this situation, the client cannot change blocks (too late for that), but the block never shows up so the slot ends up empty.

author: sky.cactus
content: If the relay does this over and over, you end up with the only people who actually submit blocks are people who are *not* running MEV Boost.  If most validators are running MEV Boost (because it is very profitable to do so), then we have an outage.

author: mosheblox
content: I see, thanks!

author: tersec
content: I don't think there's necessarily that much disagreement with this in principle, but my read is the concern is that people were going to want MEV on day 0/day 1, the only difference being whether it was out in the open and broadly available or restricted to a few staking pools. The fix for this is L1 PBS.

author: tersec
content: But that's not for a while.

author: tersec
content: The current plans specifically create incentive cryptoeconomic alignment between builders and proposers, which, as discussed here, the builder API doesn't
